awd_titl_txt: Case Adjudication as Local Practice: A Follow-up Study using Multiple Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Criminal courts that operate under the same formal law and policy often develop their own norms and practices, resulting in very different kinds of justice outcomes depending upon where a case is adjudicated. And when formal legal policies change, the reforms generally get implemented in distinct and divergent ways by local court actors, sometimes in ways inconsistent with policy goals. This project capitalizes upon recent major policy changes imposed in the federal criminal system by the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) to examine how different court "communities" have responded to the changes. Specifically, new policies have been developed urging prosecutors to focus on certain kinds of federal crimes, and that require prosecutors across the country to maximize the potential punishment. While the DOJ policies aim for standardized prosecutorial practices across the diverse federal district courts, prior research suggests that local courts will vary in how they translate these directives into action.  
 
The study builds directly upon the PI's previous NSF-funded research that examined jurisdictional differences in adjudication strategies in federal court, using both qualitative field methods and quantitative methods. The project revisits the same research sites (4 geographically and demographically diverse federal districts) to assess whether and how the current DOJ policy impacts caseload characteristics (including defendant demography) and adjudication practices and outcomes, with a focus on how formal top-down policy is translated into localized, on-the-ground legal action. Using interviews, observations, and administrative data from the federal courts, the project tests three related hypotheses: 1) Despite the return to policies that aim to control local practices through top-down mandates, adaptations will be localized in practice. Between-district variations will continue to be evident in four distinct sets of practices: case selection; prosecutorial charging practices; terms and modes of plea agreements; and formal sentencing practices. 2) Within-district, demographic composition of the caseload, the application of prosecutorial-controlled sentencing tools, and sentence lengths will change as a function of temporal period, but local adjudication norms will temper such change. 3) The degree of change in local practice norms will be greater in the current policy period (beginning May, 2017) than the previous one (2010-2017) because the current policy authorizes increased punishment for defendants and includes local compliance mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Beginning in 2017, the Trump administration's U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) instituted a series of new internal policies that required federal prosecutors across the country to maximize the potential punishment against criminal defendants in federal court, a reversal of policies and practices instituted during the Obama administration, and that encouraged them to focus on prosecuting certain kinds of federal crimes, such as drug, immigration, and gun offenses. This project capitalized upon those major policy changes imposed in the federal criminal system by the DOJ to examine how different federal court "communities" have responded to those changes.

The study builds directly upon the PI's previous NSF-funded research that examined jurisdictional differences in criminal case adjudication strategies in federal court, using both qualitative field methods and quantitative methods, to focus on how four distinct federal courts varied in translating law and policy into practices. In the follow-up study, the PI conducted interviews, made field observations, and examined case files from the same research sites (4 geographically and demographically diverse federal districts) to assess whether and how the DOJ policy reforms impacted caseload characteristics and adjudication practices and outcomes, focusing on how formal top-down policy was translated into localized, on-the-ground legal action. The PI also analyzed national federal case outcome data to quantitatively examine such changes more broadly, and over a longer period of time. 

The findings from the qualitative portion of the study indicate that prosecutors adapted to the policy mandates differently, depending on local conditions. For instance, while all four jurisdictions pursued many more immigration cases during the Trump era, two of the districts creatively deployed law and policy to also increase the level of punishment imposed on immigration defendants.

In the quantitative analysis, which used U.S. Sentencing Commission data from 2004-2019 to model outcomes for several measures of prosecutorial discretion to test the impact of the policy changes on case processing outcomes, the PI found a significant effect of the policy reforms on how prosecutorial tools are used across multiple policy periods. There was also significant variation across districts in policy responses as a function of contextual conditions, consistent with the court-communities literature. A powerful driver of changes in prosecutorial practices during the Trump administration was the confirmation of individual Trump-appointed U.S. Attorneys at the district level, suggesting an important theoretical place for mid-level actors in policy translation and implementation.
